Chappell, Simon P wrote:

> Here's one for you:
> 
> I'm helping some of our COBOL programmers learn Java in their own time 
> and once a week I do a small lunchtime "chalk and talk" session. Lately, 
> I have started introducing JUnit, on the grounds that the sooner I teach 
> them good habits, the more likely they are to stick with them. I'm using 
> the java.lang.String class as the object being tested, so that we only 
> have to worry about writing one class instead of two.
> 
> My question is: When testing overloaded methods (String.indexOf() in 
> this specific case), is it better for each overloaded method get it's 
> own testXXX() method or is it ok to lump them all in the one test? I 
> have them all in one test right now, on the grounds that the test is 
> against the index feature, rather than the individual methods.
> 
> Thoughts please.

I prefer one assertion per test. (I am not going to debate this again, 
as I did on, I believe, the TDD or XP list for some weeks.) As a result, 
each time I verify indexOf(), it would likely be in a different test.

Lumping the assertions in one test:
PRO: Easier to write the test
CON: If assertion #3 fails, assertion #5 never executes

This is a specific case of putting five tests (or n, for some n > 1) 
into one test. If one of those assertions fails, the whole test fails. 
Is that the behavior you'd expect? If not, then write separate tests. If 
so, then write it as one big test.
